video.title: Vim Tutorial for Beginners
video.description:
Vim is a highly configurable text editor that you can use for software development or any kind of text editing. In this course you will learn how to use and exit Vim.

✏️ Florian Dedov from NeuralNine developed this course. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC8wZnXYK_CGKlBcZp-GxYPA

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: NeuralNine
topLevelComment.text: Hope I was able to motivate some of you guys to learn Vim with this course. It is not as hard as it looks and it pays off. If you are interested in more Vim, Python and programming content in general, feel free to check out my channel. :)

topLevelComment.author: Jacob Moena
topLevelComment.text: The biggest reason for why you'd want to learn to use a text editing environment like Vim or Emacs is that using the keyboard allows you to get the commands into your muscle memory. It's like playing an instrument. After training, your fingers automatically perform complex motions without you thinking about it. That's something that you will never ever be able to using a mouse and menus. I am an Emacs user, but I am watching this to learn Vim (read Neovim) because that's the only thing that I can make run on my old and seriously weak Celeron based laptop.

topLevelComment.author: Ahk all the way!
topLevelComment.text: A lot of people probably already know about this, but there's `:x`, which writes *only* if there were changes and then quits regardless. With `:wq`, you write whether or not there were changes, potentially wasting time, so `:x` is more efficient

topLevelComment.author: Ahk all the way!
topLevelComment.text: In the terminal, while you're writing a command or file path, you can press tab to autocomplete it. If there's more than one suggestion, you can press tab twice to see a list of all suggestions

topLevelComment.author: Ahk all the way!
topLevelComment.text: While in the terminal, (at least in zsh, not sure about bash), you can press ^u to delete the whole line, instead of holding down backspace. If you want to go word by word in deleting, you can use ^w.

topLevelComment.author: Haraldur Karlsson
topLevelComment.text: I think most younger folks that grew up in the modern era may not realize that the early computers were all operated from the keyboard.  The Apollo landing computer only had a 3 by 5 keyboard (0-9, +, -) and some seven other main keys (CLR, PRG, ENTER, RESET etc).  Hence was natural to find short-cuts for typing in commands quickly - an art that vanished with the emergence of the mouse (a concept Xerox invented and Jobs adapted in his Mac computer).

topLevelComment.author: Shail 012
topLevelComment.text:
VIM starter pack 
many useful comands of normal mode
i (go to insert mode)
ESC or <CTRL>{ (go to normal mode)
:w
:q (quit)
:wq (save and quit)
:q! (quit without saving)

dd (delete line)
3dd  (delete 3 line)
di{ (delete everything inside "{" )
dt{ (delete everything till "{" )
df{ (delete everything till "{"  including "{")

cc (change line)
3dd  (change 3 line)

ci{ (change  everything inside "{" )
ct{ (change everything till "{" )
cf{ (change everything till "{"  including "{")

/void (find void and highlight it)
:noh (no highligh)

y (copy selected text)
yy (copy current line)
p (paste)
u (undo)
:E (open file manager to select file and open file in another tab)
:E. (open file manager and open file in current tab)
:e test.txt (open test.txt)
<CTRL> y (redo)

replies.author: Richard Assal
replies.text:
@TxzK You’re funny. In VS you just click the line number and hit the delete key. You just double click the word and hit the delete key. Just brush the mouse and hit the delete key. Jump to the beginning the file drag the scroll bar. Jump to the end drag the scroll bar. It’s more intuitive to use the mouse. 

I used to use Vim 15 years ago. But now I just use a normal GUI IDE. when you say it’s faster. You are talking about 1 second instead of 2 seconds. Intuitive use lasts longer in memory  that having to memorize cryptic  instructions.

replies.author: TxzK
replies.text: Bruh all of what you said is wrong. Vim is extremely powerful and efficient. You can do everything VSCode can, customize the hell out of it and most importantly it can speed you up with it's key binding. You want to delete a line? just press ESC and type dd. a word? dw. From cursor to end of line? d$. jump to the begining of file: gg. End of file? gG etc. It's so much faster than using a mouse.
